concepts.concept_name: Taking care of our body systems

in_scope: Digestive organs: mouth, food pipe, stomach, intestines
Digestion: breaking down food for energy
Respiratory organs: nose, windpipe, lungs
Breathing: inhaling oxygen, exhaling carbon dioxide
Heart pumps blood throughout the body
Blood carries oxygen and food to all body parts
Bones give shape and support to body
Major bones: skull, ribs, backbone, arm bones, leg bones
Importance of exercise, good food, and rest
out_of_scope: Detailed organ structure - Introduced in Class 5
Nervous system - Introduced in Class 4
Excretory system - Introduced in Class 5
Muscular system in detail - Introduced in Class 5

concepts.concept_name: Parts of a plant and their functions
Types of plants based on habitat
Importance of plants to living things

in_scope: Root: absorbs water and minerals, holds plant in soil
Stem: carries water and food, supports plant
Leaf: makes food for plant using sunlight
Flower: helps plant reproduce
Plants need sunlight, water, air, and soil to make food
Desert plants: thick stems, small leaves (cactus)
Water plants: floating leaves, flexible stems (lotus)
Mountain plants: small size, needle-like leaves
Plants give oxygen, food, medicine, wood, paper
out_of_scope: Detailed photosynthesis process - Introduced in Class 5
Plant reproduction in detail - Introduced in Class 5
Plant tissues - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Classification of animals (mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, amphibians, insects)

in_scope: Mammals: have fur, give birth to babies, feed milk
Birds: have feathers, beaks, lay eggs, most can fly
Reptiles: have scales, cold-blooded, lay eggs
Fish: live in water, have fins and gills, lay eggs
Amphibians: live on land and water (frog)
Insects: have six legs, three body parts
Adaptations: camouflage, sharp claws, thick fur, wings
Food chain: grass to grasshopper to frog to snake
Herbivores eat plants, carnivores eat meat, omnivores eat both
out_of_scope: Detailed classification (kingdom, phylum) - Introduced in Class 7
Animal reproduction - Introduced in Class 5
Migration patterns - Introduced in Class 5

in_scope: Carbohydrates: give energy (rice, bread, potato)
Proteins: help body grow (milk, eggs, dal, meat)
Fats: give energy and warmth (butter, oil, nuts)
Vitamins and minerals: keep us healthy (fruits, vegetables)
Water: needed for all body functions
Balanced diet: eating all types of food in right amounts
Food groups: energy-giving, body-building, protective foods
Simple preservation: refrigeration, drying, pickling
out_of_scope: Specific vitamins (A, B, C, D) in detail - Introduced in Class 5
Deficiency diseases - Introduced in Class 5
Digestion process in detail - Introduced in Class 5

concepts.concept_name: States of matter: solids, liquids, gases
Properties of solids, liquids, and gases
Materials around us and their uses

in_scope: Solids: have fixed shape and size (stone, wood, ice)
Liquids: take shape of container, can flow (water, milk, oil)
Gases: no fixed shape or size, fill entire space (air, steam)
Melting: solid to liquid (ice to water)
Freezing: liquid to solid (water to ice)
Evaporation: liquid to gas (water to steam)
Condensation: gas to liquid (steam to water)
Materials: wood, metal, plastic, glass, cloth
out_of_scope: Molecular structure - Introduced in Class 7
Sublimation - Introduced in Class 6
Physical and chemical changes - Introduced in Class 6

in_scope: Sun heats water in rivers, lakes, seas (evaporation)
Water vapor rises and forms clouds (condensation)
Clouds release water as rain, snow, hail (precipitation)
Water flows back to rivers and seas (collection)
Cycle continues forever
Different types of clouds
Water cycle provides fresh water for all living things
Saving water: turn off taps, rainwater harvesting
out_of_scope: Groundwater systems - Introduced in Class 5
Types of precipitation in detail - Introduced in Class 5
Global water distribution - Introduced in Class 6

in_scope: Air is a mixture of gases
Main gases: nitrogen (most), oxygen (needed for breathing)
Other gases: carbon dioxide, water vapor
Properties: occupies space, has weight, can be compressed
Moving air is wind
Wind energy: windmills, sailing boats, drying clothes
Air pollution from vehicles, factories, burning
Effects: breathing problems, diseases
Solutions: planting trees, using clean energy, reducing smoke
out_of_scope: Exact percentages of gases - Introduced in Class 6
Atmospheric layers - Introduced in Class 7
Combustion and respiration - Introduced in Class 6

in_scope: Sun is a star, gives light and heat
Earth moves around the Sun (revolution)
Earth spins on its axis (rotation) - causes day and night
Moon moves around Earth, takes about 28 days
Moon phases: new moon, crescent, half moon, full moon
Eight planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune
Earth is the only planet with life (as we know)
Stars are far away suns, constellations are star patterns
out_of_scope: Planetary orbits and distances - Introduced in Class 5
Eclipses - Introduced in Class 5
Space exploration - Introduced in Class 5

in_scope: Natural resources: things from nature that we use
Air, water, soil, sunlight, plants, animals, minerals
Renewable: can be replaced (solar energy, wind, water, plants)
Non-renewable: cannot be replaced quickly (coal, oil, natural gas)
Resources for energy: coal, oil, sunlight, wind
Resources for food: plants, animals, water, soil
Conservation: using wisely, not wasting
Importance of saving resources for future
out_of_scope: Fossil fuel formation - Introduced in Class 6
Mining and extraction - Introduced in Class 6
Energy crisis - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Our role in protecting the environment

in_scope: Air pollution: smoke from vehicles, factories
Water pollution: dirty water from factories, garbage in rivers
Land pollution: garbage, plastic waste
Effects: diseases, harm to animals and plants
Reduce: use less, avoid waste
Reuse: use things again instead of throwing
Recycle: make new things from old materials
Protecting wildlife: not hunting, preserving forests
Planting trees, keeping surroundings clean
out_of_scope: Global warming and climate change - Introduced in Class 5
Ozone layer - Introduced in Class 7
Biodiversity in detail - Introduced in Class 6
